questions.question:
Question 1: Which of the following is the most common surgery done for tubotympanic type of chronic 
suppurative otitis media?
questions.explanation:
Tympanoplasty is the most common surgery done in the tubotympanic type of CSOM. It involves ossiculoplasty (the eradication of the disease from the middle ear and repair of 
ossicles) with or without myringoplasty (repair of perforation of the tympanic membrane, which is 
done to check repeated infections from external ear).

questions.question:
Question 2: As a first-year ENT resident, you are preparing a patient for tympanoplasty. Which of the 
following would not be in your pre-operative checklist?
questions.explanation:
142 
Sold by @itachibot CT scan of the temporal bone is not required in tympanoplasty procedures. It is required only in 
cases of mastoidectomy. For tympanoplasty, routine blood investigations, pure tone audiometry, and an X-ray of the 
mastoid are sufficient.

questions.question: Question 3: Wullstein’s classification is used for which of the following procedures?
questions.explanation: Zollner and Wullstein’s classification is used to classify tympanoplasty.

questions.question:
Question 4: A 30-year-old man presents with complaints of painless, odourless and profuse discharge 
from the right ear. An otoscopic image of the affected ear is given below. Which of the 
following would not be a part of the management? 135 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and image showing a medium central perforation of the pars tensa is 
suggestive of tubo-tympanic type (TTD) of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM). Canal wall 
down mastoidectomy is not a part of the management plan. This is only performed in attico-antral type and in cases of tubo-tympanic type where a reservoir 
of infection in the middle ear is suspected. Management of tubo-tympanic type of CSOM: • Medical management: • Aural toilet • Topical antibiotics with steroid drops • Systemic antibiotics • Treatment of causative factors. • Surgical management: • It is done once the ear is dry for 6 weeks without antibiotics. • Tympanoplasty (ossiculoplasty with or without myringoplasty).

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following is the most common graft material used for tympanoplasty?
questions.explanation:
Temporalis fascia is the most common graft material used for tympanoplasty Other graft materials used are: • The areolar fascia overlying the temporal fascia • Perichondrium from the tragus • Conchal cartilage • Vein • Periosteum 143 
Sold by @itachibot Dura mater was used earlier but then discontinued due to the risk of prion diseases like 
Cruetzfeldt Jacob disease.

questions.question:
Question 6: A patient having chronic otitis media with perforation of pars tensa is scheduled for 
myringoplasty to restore hearing. Which of the following is true regarding the techniques 
used here?

options.a: In underlay technique, graft is placed medial to annulus
options.b: In underlay technique, graft is placed lateral to malleus
options.c: In overlay technique, graft is placed medial to annulus
options.d: In overlay technique, graft is placed lateral to malleus

questions.explanation:
In the underlay technique, the graft is placed medial to the annulus. Whereas, in the overlay 
technique, the graft is placed lateral to the annulus. The graft is medial to malleus in both 
techniques. Myringoplasty techniques are based on the relation of the graft with lamina propria of tympanic 
membrane remnants and fibrous annulus.

questions.question:
Question 7: A patient with mucosal disease of the middle ear is set to undergo myringoplasty. Which of 
the following incisions is used here?
questions.explanation:
Wilde’s (or post-aural) incision is used in myringoplasty. Wilde's incision is used in the following: • Cortical mastoidectomy • Modified radical and radical mastoidectomy • Tympanoplasty - when perforation extends anterior to handle of malleus • Exposure of CN VII in the vertical segment • Surgery of endolymphatic sac. Option A: Killian’s incision is used in submucous resection surgery for deviated nasal septum. In 
cases of a deviated septum, a slightly curvilinear incision is made, 2–3 mm behind the caudal end 
of septal cartilage at the mucocutaneous junction, always on the left side. 144 
Sold by @itachibot Option B: Freer’s hemitransfixion incision is used in septoplasty done for deviated nasal 
septum. In case of caudal dislocation, a transfixion or hemitransfixion incision is made. It is a 
septocolumellar incision between the caudal end of septal cartilage and columella on the concave 
side. Option D: Gluck–Sorenson’s incision used for laryngectomy with radical neck dissection.

questions.question:
Question 8: Austin’s classification for anatomical defects in the ossicular chain is based on which of the 
following structures?
questions.explanation:
Austin's classification of anatomical defects in the ossicular chain is based on the presence or 
absence of handle of malleus and stapes suprastructure. Incus is the most common bone to be eroded and assuming it to be absent in most cases, the 
remaining 2 ossicles, i.e., malleus and stapes are considered for the classification.

questions.question:
Question 9: A patient presents to your OPD with hearing difficulty and scanty, foul-smelling discharge 
from the left ear. Otologic examination reveals the following finding. What is the treatment of 
choice in this condition? 137 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario describes a case of atticoantral type of CSOM and modified radical 
mastoidectomy is the treatment of choice here. Option A: Myringotomy is done in cases of acute suppurative otitis media (ASOM) and serous 
otitis media. Options C and D: Medical management followed by myringoplasty or tympanoplasty once the ear 
is dry for 6 weeks without antibiotics is the treatment of choice for tubotympanic type of CSOM.

questions.question:
Question 10: A 7-year-old child presents with scanty, foul-smelling ear discharge. Otologic examination 
shows the following finding. Which of the following is an appropriate management plan?
questions.explanation:
145 
Sold by @itachibot The given clinical scenario along with the image showing marginal perforation is suggestive of 
atticoantral type of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM), and the appropriate management 
plan is surgical intervention with tympanomastoid exploration.

questions.question:
Question 11: What would be the primary aim of surgery in a patient presenting with the following 
otoscopic finding?
questions.explanation:
The given image shows a white mass located in the anterosuperior quadrant behind the intact 
eardrum suggestive of cholesteatoma. The primary aim is to clear the disease and render the ear 
safe. The second priority is to preserve or reconstruct the hearing, but never at the cost of the 
primary aim.

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following is not seen in a case of otitis media?
questions.explanation:
Battle sign refers to retro auricular or mastoid ecchymosis that typically results from a fracture of 
the middle cranial fossa following head trauma. It is prominent when there is a fracture of 
the temporal bone. Battle sign is not seen in the case of otitis media. 146 
Sold by @itachibot Option A: Bezold abscess is a complication of acute otomastoiditis where the infection/pus breaks 
through the thin medial side of the tip of the mastoid and presents as a swelling in the upper part 
of the neck. Option B: Griesinger sign refers to edema of the postauricular soft tissues overlying 
the mastoid process as a result of thrombosis of the mastoid emissary vein seen in sigmoid sinus 
thrombosis. It is a complication of acute otomastoiditis. Option D: Delta sign is a contrast-enhanced CT finding seen in sagittal sinus thrombosis, which 
can occur as a complication of acute mastoiditis or chronic suppurative otitis media. It is a 
triangular area with rim enhancement and the central low-density area is seen in the posterior 
cranial fossa on axial cuts. MR venography is useful to assess the progression or resolution of a 
thrombus. The image below depicts a filling defect (thrombus) outlined by contrast medium in the sagittal 
sinus. 147 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 14: A patient complains of severe pain in his right ear associated with high-grade fever and 
profuse ear discharge. Clinical examination reveals mastoid tenderness and perforation of the 
tympanic membrane. If this infection were to burst out through the medial aspect of the tip of 
the mastoid, which of the following conditions would ensue?
questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario of severe pain in his right ear associated with high-grade fever, profuse ear 
discharge, mastoid tenderness, and perforation of the tympanic membrane is suggestive of acute 
mastoiditis, which has most likely occurred as a complication of acute infection of the middle ear. 
If this infection is to burst out through the medial side of the tip of the mastoid, it results in the 
formation of Bezold abscess. Acute mastoiditis is used to refer to an acute infection that spreads from the mucosa, lining the 
mastoid air cells, to involve the bony walls of the mastoid air cell system. The image below shows a picture of acute mastoiditis: Blood leukocytes and ESR is raised. CT scan of the temporal bone shows clouding of air cells due 
to the collection of exudate in them. In later stages, a cavity may be seen in the mastoid. 
Treatment is done by administration of intravenous antibiotics and if indicated, surgical 
procedures such as myringotomy and cortical mastoidectomy. Abscesses in Relation to mastoid infection are: • Bezold abscess lies deep to the sternocleidomastoid and presents as a swelling in the tip of the 
mastoid or the angle of the jaw and is seen in the upper part of the posterior triangle or the 
parapharyngeal space The images below show a picture of Bezold abscess: 148 
Sold by @itachibot Other abscesses in relation to mastoid infection: • Post auricular abscess - it is the most common abscess that forms over the mastoid. In infants 
and children, this presents over the MacEwen’s triangle. • Zygomatic abscess - infection of the zygomatic air cells. It is situated at the posterior root of the 
zygoma • Luc abscess (meatal abscess) - the pus breaks through the bony wall between the mastoid 
antrum and external auditory meatus • Citelli’s abscess - the abscess is formed posterior to the mastoid, occupying a position more 
towards the occipital bone 149 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 15: A 30-year-old woman presented with a history of ear discharge in the left ear for the past 4 
weeks, deep-seated ear pain for the past 1 week, and diplopia for the past 2 days. What is the 
most probable diagnosis in this scenario?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Gradenigo’s syndrome, which occurs secondary to 
petrous apicitis. This is a complication of otitis media. The triad of Gradenigo's syndrome consists of: • Ipsilateral abducens nerve palsy (6th nerve palsy) - external rectus palsy • Deep ear/facial pain (5th nerve involvement) • Persistent ear discharge (otitis media) The incidence of this syndrome has reduced with the advent of antibiotics. Option A- Following acute coalescent mastoiditis the pus breaks through the bony wall between 
the mastoid antrum and the external meatus and forms Luc's abscess. The swelling can burst into 
the meatus causing otorrhea. Options B and C- Nasopharyngeal carcinoma and trigeminal schwannoma can present with 
cranial nerve palsy, but they do not follow the above clinical course.

questions.question: Question 16: In which of the following conditions would you expect to see Griesinger’s sign?
questions.explanation:
Griesinger’s sign is seen in sigmoid sinus thrombosis. It is described as mastoid tenderness and 
edema, which is secondary to thrombophlebitis of the mastoid emissary vein. However, Gradenigo's syndrome/triad is a complication of otitis media and is seen when the 
infection extends to the petrous apex (petrositis). The triad consists of: • Ipsilateral abducens nerve palsy (6th nerve palsy) - external rectus palsy • Deep ear/facial pain (5th nerve involvement) 150 
Sold by @itachibot • Persistent ear discharge (otitis media)

questions.question:
Question 17: A patient with a history of foul-smelling ear discharge, for which he did not complete 
treatment now presents with complaints of fever with chills and swelling over the mastoid. 
On examination, there is tenderness along the jugular vein. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of lateral sinus thrombophlebitis. It is an inflammation of 
the inner wall of the lateral venous sinus with the formation of an intrasinus thrombus. Clinical features of lateral sinus thrombophlebitis: • Hectic picket fence fever with chills and rigors. This is due to septicemia. The clinical picture 
resembles malaria but lacks regularity. • Headache - In the early stage, it may be due to peri-sinus abscess and is mild. Later, it may be 
severe when intracranial pressure rises due to venous obstruction. • Griesinger’s sign - this is due to thrombosis of the mastoid emissary vein. Edema appears over 
the posterior part of the mastoid. • Papilloedema - its presence depends on obstruction to venous return. It is often seen with the 
right sinus (which is larger than the left). • Tenderness along the jugular vein - This is seen when thrombophlebitis extends along the 
jugular vein. There may be associated enlargement and inflammation of the jugular chain of 
lymph nodes and torticollis. Investigations: • Blood culture • CSF analysis - normal except for increased CSF pressure that helps in ruling out meningitis. • X-ray mastoid shows: • Clouding of air cells seen in acute mastoiditis. • Destruction of bone seen in cholesteatoma. • CECT shows a typical delta sign. 151 
Sold by @itachibot Treatment: • Intravenous antibacterial therapy • Mastoidectomy and exposure of sinus • Ligation of internal jugular vein • Anticoagulant therapy

questions.question:
Question 18: A patient with hearing loss has the following otoscopic finding. What is the treatment 
modality of choice?
questions.explanation:
The image shows a cherry-red small mass of granulation tissue arising from the pars flaccida of 
the left tympanic membrane strongly suggesting that there is an underlying cholesteatoma in the 
attic area. Surgery is the treatment of choice in case of cholesteatoma. The continuing discharge from the granulation tissue has caused the surface epithelia of the 
tympanic membrane to become edematous and thickened. This gives the surface of the tympanic 
membrane a thickened whitish appearance. The primary aim in surgical treatment is to remove the disease and render the ear safe, and 
second in priority is to preserve or reconstruct hearing but never at the cost of the primary aim. 
Mastoidectomy is done. 152 
Sold by @itachibot Otosclerosis
